human_readable_transcript:
Before continuing with the previous CHECKLIST, please triage if the patient mentions anything that indicates that they have ran out of medications in the past week. Today is December 19, 2023 and time is 08:04 PM. Patient is 73 years old. Patient's gender is female. Patient is actively suffering with the following conditions: Stage IV CKD, Type II Diabetes, Multiple Back Surgeries, Hyperlipidemia. Patient is currently taking the following medications: Metformin 500 mg oral tablet, Tylenol 500 mg oral tablet, Atorvastatin 40 mg oral tablet. Use the following questions to triage the ran_out_of_meds kickout. Be concise and ONLY acknowledge or respond to the patient's response by saying nothing or 'Okay'. DO NOT say you are sorry or that you see or that you understand.
Please follow the order of the follow up questions exactly as listed below. DO NOT skip any question:
1. Confirm again with the patient you heard them correctly that they have ran out of medications in the past week. If the patient answers negatively, skip the rest of the questions.
2. What medication did the patient run out of
3. Does the patient have any refills for a medication
4. Does the patient have any more information they want to share about this issue?

After all the follow up questions are done, please continue with the CHECKLIST where you left off.
</KICKOUT_CHECKLIST><</SYS>>
Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital on a recorded line. Is this Ana Aguirre? 

 Patient: It's Anna. Yes. 

 Nurse: Thanks for taking my call. Just so you know, I'm your AI Chronic Care Manager. Thousands of real doctors and nurses helped train me to care for patients like you. I've also studied hundreds of medical certification exams and your care team provided me with notes to prepare for this call. -- To protect your privacy, can you please share your date of birth before we begin? 

 Patient: Yes. March fourteenth nineteen fifty. 

 Nurse: Thank you for confirming that, Ms. Aguirre. I'm calling on behalf of your primary care doctor, Doctor Lynne Contreras, to check in on you and see how you're doing. Can you share with me how you've been feeling lately? 

 Patient: I've been feeling okay. Thank you so much. Yeah. Just trying to manage everything and just really been on top of it. You know, I don't know how much I have left to live, so I really really, really I love everyday, and just simply really, really grateful for this day for today. 

 Nurse: I'm really glad to hear that you're feeling okay and that you're embracing each day with such positivity, Ms. Aguirre. It's truly inspiring. Before we delve into the topics I have to cover, I'd like to get to know you a little better. Is there anything you're looking forward to doing this week? 

 Patient: Yes. Well, it's holidays, 

 Nurse: That sounds exciting! Holidays are always a special time. 

 Patient: and I I don't really celebrate 

 Nurse: Oh, Okay -- Is there a particular reason you don't celebrate holidays, or is it just a personal preference? 

 Patient: Well, I wasn't able to finish my sentence, you cut me off. So that's not actually what I intended to say. I was gonna say that I don't celebrate Christmas. But it's just nice to have a few days off and relax a bit. 

 Nurse: I apologize for interrupting you earlier, Ms. Aguirre. It's indeed wonderful to have a few days off to relax. Do you have any special plans for your days off, or do you prefer to take things as they come? 

 Patient: Depends. I have a few plans, but just going to read some things and read some books that I've been postponing So I'm looking forward to that. 

 Nurse: That sounds like a lovely way to spend your time off. Reading can be such a great escape. What kind of books do you enjoy? Any particular genre or author you're fond of? 

 Patient: I like novel. I like everything. I love memoirs, like, born a crime by Trevor Noah. So so good. I'm halfway through 

 Nurse: That's wonderful! Trevor Noah's "Born a Crime" is indeed a compelling read. It's great to see you have a diverse taste in books. How do you find the memoir so far? Is there something specific that you like about it? 

 Patient: Yeah. I mean, just the whole apartment era in Africa, and it's just really, really good good to know to understand that part of the world and through Trevor Noah's Lance who was literally born a crime 

 Nurse: It's truly fascinating to learn about different parts of the world and their histories through personal narratives like Trevor Noah's. It's a unique lens to view the world. Before we move on to discuss your health, I wanted to ask if there are any symptoms or health concerns you've been experiencing lately that you'd like to discuss? 

 Patient: No. But, you know, I was going through my meth, and I ran out of meds, and I don't know what to do. And I've Patient: completely forgot. Patient: Completely forgot to refill it Patient: So help me out, Rachel. 

 Nurse: Okay -- Just to confirm, you mentioned that you ran out of your medications in the past week, is that correct? 

 Patient: Yes. I just ran out of meds. Patient: Yes. 


 <<SYS>> <TASK>Please ask the next follow up question from the <KICKOUT_CHECKLIST> section for the ran_out_of_meds kickout. DO NOT respond to how the patient is feeling.</TASK><</SYS>>


 Nurse:

responses.G15: I see. Could you please tell me which medication you ran out of?
responses.G15DPO: Which medication did you run out of?
responses.gpt4: Could you please tell me which medication you ran out of?
